commit_message:
Check for enabled service in d6cage

Calling APIs from datasource drivers when the service is not enabled causes
exceptions. This is avoided by pre-checking the service enablement before
loading the datasource module for the service.

eg: If ceilometer is not enabled, ceilometer driver is not loaded.

Change includes a check in create service to check if the service corresponding
to the driver module being loaded is enabled by probing into keystone service
list.
Also harness is modified to first add the name of service in system_services
before calling createservice for services like "engine", "api-rule" etc.. so
that the check for service enablement is not done on these. (Obviously, there
are no services in keystone for the modules owned by the policy engine and
APIs.)
The createservice() function returns a True/False attribute before harness
tries to call initialization apis for the module like
get_schema/get_translators etc...

The datasources for which the services are not enabled are not listed for the
command "openstack congress datasource list"

Fixes Bug #1395224

Change-Id: I450ba93bcc481edf546259ffdc19920d84c827b5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/48/137548/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from congress.datasources import datasource_utilsimport keystoneclient.v2_0.client as kc # Check if the service for this module is enabled enabled_service = False if name not in self.system_service_names: creds = datasource_utils.get_credentials(name, args) kclient = kc.Client(**creds) service_list = kclient.services.list() for service in service_list: srv = service.to_dict() LOG.debug("Reading for Service %s" % str(srv)) if srv['name'] == name: enabled_service = srv['enabled'] else: enabled_service = True if enabled_service: try: svcObject = module.d6service(name, keys, inbox, self.dataPath, args) self.greenThreadPool.spawn(svcObject.switch) self.greenThreads.append(svcObject) except Exception: raise DataServiceError( "Error loading service '%s' of module '%s':: \n%s" % (name, module, traceback.format_exc())) self.log_info("created service: %s", name) self.services[name] = {} self.services[name]['name'] = name self.services[name]['description'] = description self.services[name]['moduleName'] = moduleName self.services[name]['keys'] = keys self.services[name]['args'] = args self.services[name]['object'] = svcObject self.services[name]['inbox'] = inbox try: self.table.add(name, inbox) localname = "local." + name self.table.add(localname, inbox) self.subscribe( name, 'routeKeys', callback=self.updateRoutes, interval=5) self.publish('services', self.services) except Exception, errmsg: del self.services[name] raise DataServiceError( "error starting service '%s': %s" % (name, errmsg)) else: return True else: LOG.info("Service %s of module %s is not enabled" % (name, module)) return False
deleted_lines: try: svcObject = module.d6service(name, keys, inbox, self.dataPath, args) self.greenThreadPool.spawn(svcObject.switch) self.greenThreads.append(svcObject) except Exception: raise DataServiceError( "Error loading service '%s' of module '%s':: \n%s" % (name, module, traceback.format_exc())) self.log_info("created service: %s", name) self.services[name] = {} self.services[name]['name'] = name self.services[name]['description'] = description self.services[name]['moduleName'] = moduleName self.services[name]['keys'] = keys self.services[name]['args'] = args self.services[name]['object'] = svcObject self.services[name]['inbox'] = inbox try: self.table.add(name, inbox) localname = "local." + name self.table.add(localname, inbox) self.subscribe( name, 'routeKeys', callback=self.updateRoutes, interval=5) self.publish('services', self.services) except Exception, errmsg: del self.services[name] raise DataServiceError( "error starting service '%s': %s" % (name, errmsg))

commit_message:
Update cinder driver using datasource translators

Modified cinder driver to use translators as per updated datasource driver
syntax. Also use register_translators() in the driver.

Change-Id: I339ea11eca688af47f87d17ff3794df19a628b68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/60/140260/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Added logging for datasource data conversion

Now if you provide some context information, the
DatasourceDriver base class will log the input/output
of its conversion process from raw data to database tables.
This is useful for debugging datasource drivers.

Change-Id: Ifc4d61230a6baba421579dbaf53d2bb991dd5a40

commit_message:
implement timestamp for Project, Role

Give a simple way to determine when Project and Role resources were
created and when they were last modified: add created_at and
updated_at attributes for Project and Role.

bp model-timestamps

Change-Id: I8ec48a5ceff55ecd552945d7a4312aacaba7f32f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/14/153114/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================ model-timestamps ================ `bp model-timestamps <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/model-timestamps>`_ Currently Project, Domain, Role, User, Group models don't have a timestamp. There is no way to determine when these resources were created and when they were last modified. This can be a huge problem for auditing, administration, etc. We don't want to make one spec that fixes all models. So, this spec will only implement timestamp for assignment models: Project, Domain, Role. Problem Description =================== * For auditing, we may want to know how many projects were created or modified at a time interval. * For administration, we may want to know when a project was created or last modified. Proposed Change =============== Actually, oslo_db has provided a TimestampMixin object for timestamp models. The only thing we need to do is to make Project, Domain, Role inherit from TimestampMixin and then add a db migration script. Alternatives ------------ None Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: w-wanghong (wanghong <w.wanghong@huawei.com>) Work Items ---------- * Update Project, Domain, Role model to inherit TimestampMixin * Write db migration script * Add tests Dependencies ============ None Documentation Impact ==================== Update the Projects, Domains, Roles sections of documentation. References ========== ` oslo_db models <https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/sqlalchemy/models.py#L115>`_

commit_message:
Serial Console Procedure

Adding a procedure for setting up and configuring
access to the Serial Console, allowing users to
access nova servers.

Change-Id: I2427f94d60cc5a4b8425312fadb8266e11017160
backport: none
Closes-Bug: #1363954
Co-Authored-By: Matt Kassawara <mkassawara@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/33/149533/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <simplesect> <title>Serial Console Support</title> <para>A useful support option for examining kernal output and other messages is the serial console. If you do not have network access needed to view server activity, the serial console can provide a platform to view information, and check for errors.</para> <para>A read-only version of the output can be configured following the directions described in the <link linkend="section_compute-empty-log-output">Troubleshoot Compute</link> section on empty log outputs for Linux instancs.</para> <para>For a read and write version, adjust the settings configured in the <filename>nova.conf</filename>:</para> <procedure> <title>Configure Serial Console Support</title> <step> <para>Specify the <filename>[serial_console]</filename> setting in the <filename>nova.conf</filename>, by setting <command>enabled=true</command>:</para> <screen> [serial_console] enabled=true </screen> <para>This enables <command>os-getSerialConsole</command> server actions.</para> </step> <step> <para>Proivide values for the <filename>base_url</filename> <filename>listen</filename>, and <filename>proxyclient_address</filename>:</para> <screen> [serial_console] enabled=true # Location of serial console proxy. (string value) base_url=ws://127.0.0.1:6083/ # IP address on which instance serial console should listen # (string value) listen=127.0.0.1 # The address to which proxy clients (like nova-serialproxy) # should connect (string value) proxyclient_address=127.0.0.1 </screen> <para>The <filename>base_url</filename> specifies information to be passed on to clients. This address could be one of your "front-end" controllers. The URL entered here is sent when a remote client sends a serial console request.</para> <para><filename>Nova-compute</filename> uses the <command>listen</command> address to control which address the console will listen in on. this can be set to 0.0.0.0 to listen on all available addresses.</para> <para>Specifying the <command>proxyclient_address</command> provides the <command>nova-serialproxy</command> with a port address to use for a connection.</para> <para>Enabling serial console support produces entries in the XML description of libvirt guests started be nova that resemble the following example:</para> <screen> <console type='tcp'> <source mode='bind' host='127.0.0.1' service='10000'/> <protocol type='raw'/> <target type='serial' port='0'/> <alias name='serial0'/> </console> </screen> </step> <step> <para>Use the <command>nova get-serial-proxy</command> command to retrieve the websocket URL for the server's serial console:</para> <screen> $ nova get-serial-console my-server +--------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+ | Type | Url | +--------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+ | serial | ws://127.0.0.1:6083/?token=18510769-71ad-4e5a-8348-4218b5613b3d | +--------+-----------------------------------------------------------------+ </screen> <para>Run the REST API command as an alternative to access the websocket URL:</para> <screen> curl -i 'http://127.0.0.1:8774/v2/>tenant_uuid>/servers/>server_uuid>/action' \ -X POST \ -H "Accept: application/json" \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -H "X-Auth-Project-Id: >project_id>" \ -H "X-Auth-Token: >auth_token>" \ -d '{"os-getSerialConsole": {"type": "serial"}}' </screen> </step> <step> <para>Record the websocket URL. After obtaining the URL, use a Python <command>websocket-client</command> to open the connection to the serial console:</para> <screen> import websocket ws = websocket.create_connection('ws://127.0.0.1:6083/?token=18510769-71ad-4e5a-8348-4218b5613b3d', subprotocols=['binary', 'base64']) </screen> <para>This will generate a <command>WebSocket</command> object with <command>.send</command> and <command>.recv</command> for receiving data, in addition to a <command>.fileno</command> method for use in event loops.</para> <note><title>Pythion WebSocket clients</title> <para>One python websocket client is available at <link xlink:href="https://github.com/larsks/novaconsole/">Github</link> (novaconsole written by Larsks).</para></note> </step> </procedure> <para>One disadvantage of configuring serial console support is that the serial console replaces the console log, which is available through the <command>nova console-log</command>.</para> <para>The end result is that if a server encountered a problem configuring networks, and sent an error report to the console, you would not readily be able to see this information.</para> </simplesect>

subject: Add info about updating db instance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-05 19:36:11.000000000', 'files': ['doc/user-guide/section_dashboard_databases.xml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/654ac92213b00598e8892fe177554703bc91aa54', 'message': 'Add info about updating db instance

User guide needs section on how to
resize db instance in dashboard.

The following commit adds the capability
to resize a database instance
(meaning assign it a new flavor) via horizon.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/108793

This commit has merged, so the doc needs

Change-Id: I37c14750353d1b4e8e0f1b4190d3f6f37adca111

commit_message:
Add info about updating db instance

User guide needs section on how to
resize db instance in dashboard.

The following commit adds the capability
to resize a database instance
(meaning assign it a new flavor) via horizon.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/108793

This commit has merged, so the doc needs
to be updated to cover this feature.

Change-Id: I37c14750353d1b4e8e0f1b4190d3f6f37adca111
Closes-Bug: #1417161
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/46/153346/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <section xml:id="dashboard_update_db"> <title>Update a database instance</title> <para>You can change various characteristics of a database instance, such as its volume size and flavor.</para> <procedure> <title>To change the volume size of an instance</title> <step> <para>Log in to the dashboard, choose a project, and click <guilabel>Databases</guilabel>.</para> </step> <step> <para>Click <guilabel>Database Instances</guilabel>. This displays the existing instances in your system.</para> </step> <step> <para>Check the instance you want to work with. In the <guilabel>Actions</guilabel> column, expand the drop down menu and select <guilabel>Resize Volume</guilabel>.</para> </step> <step> <para>In the Resize Database Volume dialog box, fill in the <guilabel>New Size</guilabel> field with an integer indicating the new size you want for the instance. Express the size in GB, and note that the new size must be larger than the current size.</para> </step> <step> <para>Click <guilabel>Resize Database Volume</guilabel>.</para> </step> </procedure> <procedure> <title>To change the flavor of an instance</title> <step> <para>Log in to the dashboard, choose a project, and click <guilabel>Databases</guilabel>.</para> </step> <step> <para>Click <guilabel>Database Instances</guilabel>. This displays the existing instances in your system.</para> </step> <step> <para>Check the instance you want to work with. In the <guilabel>Actions</guilabel> column, expand the drop down menu and select <guilabel>Resize Instance</guilabel>.</para> </step> <step> <para>In the Resize Database Instance dialog box, expand the drop down menu in the <guilabel>New Flavor</guilabel> field. Select the new flavor you want for the instance.</para> </step> <step> <para>Click <guilabel>Resize Database Instance</guilabel>.</para> </step> </procedure> </section>

Here we discuss how Alice and Bob would address common "msgstr """Earlier in <xref linkend=\"introduction-to-case-studies\"/> we introduced " "the Alice and Bob case studies where Alice is deploying a private government" " cloud and Bob is deploying a public cloud each with different security " "requirements. ""The OpenStack Identity service (keystone) supports multiple methods of ""In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would address deployment of " "PKI certification authorities (CA) and certificate management." msgstr "このケーススタディでは、アリスとボグがPKI認証局(CA)の構築と証明書管理をどのように行うのかについて解説します。"#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-messaging.xml11(title)#: ./security-guide/ch_case-studies-identity-management.xml18(title) #: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml28(title)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-networking.xml11(title)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-messaging.xml15(title)#: ./security-guide/ch_case-studies-identity-management.xml43(title) #: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml33(title)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-networking.xml29(title)"In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would address their system "msgstr "今回のケーススタディでは、アリスとボブがシステムの文書要件にどのように対処していくか見ていきます。上記で述べた文書には、ハードウェアおよびソフトウェアの記録、ネットワーク図、システム設定の詳細などが含まれます。""In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would address monitoring and"msgstr "このケーススタディでは、アリスとボブがパブリッククラウドとプライベートクラウドの中で監視とロギングを実行する方法を議論します。どちらのインスタンスでも、時間同期とログの集中保存が適切なアセスメントの実施と変則的な事のトラブル対応に極めて重要となります。単なるログの収集はそれほど有用ではなく、利用できるイベントを生成する為のロバストな監視システムを構築する必要があります。""In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would address database "msgstr "このケーススタディでは、アリスとボブがどのようにデータベースを選択し、それぞれのプライベートクラウドとパブリッククラウド用に設定するのかについて議論します。""Returning to Alice and Bob, we will use this section to dive into their " "particular tenant data privacy requirements. Specifically, we will look into" " how Alice and Bob both handle tenant data, data destruction, and data " "encryption." msgstr "アリスとボブの話に戻ると、このセクションでは、彼らの特定のテナントのデータのプライバシー要件についてより詳細に説明します。具体的には、アリスとボブの両者がテナントのデータ、データの破壊、データの暗号化をどのように対処するかを見てみます。"#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-messaging.xml12(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-messaging.xml16(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-messaging.xml17(para)"In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would ensure that their "msgstr "このケーススタディでは、アリスとボブが所有するインスタンスが正しく分離されていることを確認する方法について説明します。まずはハイパーバイザーの選択とQEMUの強化、強制アクセスコントロールの適用について検討します。""In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would address configuration "msgstr "このケーススタディでは、アリスとボブが OpenStack コアサービスの設定をどのように取り扱うかを議論します。これらには、Identity Service、Dashboard、Compute が含まれます。アリスは既存の政府ディレクトリサービスに統合することに関心があります。ボブはパブリックにアクセス権を提供する必要があります。" #: ./security-guide/ch_case-studies-identity-management.xml19(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_case-studies-identity-management.xml30(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_case-studies-identity-management.xml36(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_case-studies-identity-management.xml44(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_case-studies-identity-management.xml56(para)#: ./security-guide/ch_case-studies-identity-management.xml63(para)"to our Alice and Bob case study. Specifically, we will look into how both " "Alice and Bob will address:" msgstr "一般的な OpenStack 管理インターフェースと関連のバックプレーンの問題について、ここまでに議論しました。再度、アリスとボブのケーススタディに戻って、これらの問題を見ていきます。特に、アリスとボブが以下の点をどのように対応したかを確認していきます。" #: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml15(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml18(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml21(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml24(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml29(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml30(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml34(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-management-interfaces.xml35(para)"In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would address common "msgstr "このケーススタディでは、アリスとボブがどのように一般的なコンプライアンス要件に対応するかを説明します。これまでの章で、さまざまなコンプライアンス認証と標準について言及しました。アリスはプライベートクラウドでコンプライアンスに取り組み、いっぽうボブはパブリッククラウド向けのコンプライアンスに注力します。""In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would architect their clouds"msgstr "このケーススタディでは、アリスとボブがインスタンスのエントロピー、インスタンスのスケジューリング、信頼できるイメージ、インスタンスのマイグレーションを尊重しつつ、彼らのクラウドを設計する方法について議論します。""In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would address endpoint "msgstr "このケーススタディでは、アリスとボブがどうやってプライベートクラウドとパブリッククラウドのエンドポイント設定を堅牢化するかについて議論します。
アリスのプライベートクラウドは公開されたものではありませんが、不適切な使い方からエンドポイントを守る方法について憂慮しています。ボブのパブリッククラウドは、外部からの攻撃に対してリスクを低減する措置を講じなければいけません。""In this case study we discuss how Alice and Bob would address providing "msgstr "このケーススタディでは、アリスとボブがどのようにユーザに対してネットワーク提供を扱うかを議論します。" #: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-networking.xml12(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-networking.xml30(para)#: ./security-guide/section_case-studies-networking.xml43(para)

commit_message:
Add cloud validation (cloudv) project to stackforge

Cloud validation project is going to be used for automated validation of
a deployed cloud.
The project currently contains two subprojects:
 - OSTF adapter;
 - SDN validation tool.

Change-Id: Ia6dc95d130919a61165c1460f6a279b7524e30b6

commit_message:
Implement additional test for db migrations

Currently Manila unit tests doesn't check how many
branches exist in db migrations, but this is extremely
important, because multiple branches break
'manila db sync' command.

Implement test, which checks that db migrations has
only one branch.

Change-Id: I4125500126ba46594a636fea38480abd0c97b519
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/43/152843/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_single_branch(self): alembic_cfg = migration._alembic_config() script_directory = script.ScriptDirectory.from_config(alembic_cfg) actual_result = script_directory.get_heads() self.assertEqual(1, len(actual_result), "Db migrations should have only one branch.")

commit_message:
Make agent_ssh job not run on stable/juno Ironic patches

This causes agent_ssh to not be run against Ironic patches for
stable/juno. The job was not yet working when Juno was released, however
has been fixed and made voting since.

Alternatively, we can fix Juno devstack to make this job pass. This
patch begins that process: Ieec8cc64e504b04a21daa49e90e2d4925f4838ee

Change-Id: Ia9f3936a836ed756e03761b75a1f471e9cd501d3

commit_message:
Move puppet-tripleo to Stackforge

puppet-tripleo is the lightweight composition layer for puppet TripleO.
It needs to reside closes to TripleO Heat templates and TripleO Puppet
elements.

This module will be composed of some roles (i.e. loadbalancer) consumed
by Heat templates to setup a TripleO setup.

Change-Id: I0c12b7063a3c34448ea1ca666ef735e24d87f15b

commit_message:
Add openstack_functions.py to zuul-dev.o.o

The zuul.o.o layout.yaml file references an openstack_functions.py
This change duplicates that for zuul-dev.o.o.  To do that zuul-dev.o.o
needs it's own openstack_functions.py file.

Change-Id: Ifb8bb921545f4ab4557e02c676c85ced20687ba3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/70/153070/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2013 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import re def set_log_url(item, job, params): if hasattr(item.change, 'refspec'): path = "%s/%s/%s/%s/" % ( params['ZUUL_CHANGE'][-2:], params['ZUUL_CHANGE'], params['ZUUL_PATCHSET'], params['ZUUL_PIPELINE']) elif hasattr(item.change, 'ref'): path = "%s/%s/%s/" % ( params['ZUUL_NEWREV'][:2], params['ZUUL_NEWREV'], params['ZUUL_PIPELINE']) else: path = params['ZUUL_PIPELINE'] params['BASE_LOG_PATH'] = path params['LOG_PATH'] = path + '%s/%s/' % (job.name, params['ZUUL_UUID'][:7]) def reusable_node(item, job, params): if 'OFFLINE_NODE_WHEN_COMPLETE' in params: del params['OFFLINE_NODE_WHEN_COMPLETE'] def devstack_params(item, job, params): change = item.change # Note we can't fallback on the default labels because # jenkins uses 'devstack-precise || devstack-trusty'. # This is necessary to get the gearman plugin to register # gearman jobs with both node labels. # Remove this when we are done doing prelimindary dib testing. if 'icehouse-dibtest' in job.name: params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'devstack-precise-dib' elif 'dibtest' in job.name: params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'devstack-trusty-dib' elif ((hasattr(change, 'branch') and change.branch == 'stable/icehouse') or ('icehouse' in job.name or 'precise' in job.name)): params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'devstack-precise' elif 'centos7' in job.name: params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'devstack-centos7' elif 'aiopcpu' in job.name: params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'devstack-trusty-2-node' else: params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'devstack-trusty' def default_params_precise(item, job, params): if 'trusty' in job.name: params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'bare-trusty' else: params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'bare-precise' def default_params_trusty(item, job, params): change = item.change # Note we can't fallback on the default labels because # jenkins uses 'bare-precise || bare-trusty'. # This is necessary to get the gearman plugin to register # gearman jobs with both node labels. if ((hasattr(change, 'branch') and change.branch == 'stable/icehouse') or ('icehouse' in job.name or 'precise' in job.name)): params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'bare-precise' else: params['ZUUL_NODE'] = 'bare-trusty' def set_node_options(item, job, params, default): # Set up log url paramter for all jobs set_log_url(item, job, params) # Default to single use node. Potentially overriden below. # Select node to run job on. params['OFFLINE_NODE_WHEN_COMPLETE'] = '1' proposal_re = r'^.*(merge-release-tags|(propose|upstream)-(openstack-manuals|requirements|translation)-updates?)$' # noqa pypi_re = r'^.*-(jenkinsci|mavencentral|pypi-(both|wheel))-upload$' python26_re = r'^.*-(py(thon)?)?26.*$' centos6_re = r'^.*-centos6.*$' f20_re = r'^.*-f20.*$' f21_re = r'^.*-f21.*$' tripleo_re = r'^.*-tripleo.*$' devstack_re = r'^.*-dsvm.*$' puppetunit_re = r'^gate-puppet-.*-puppet-(lint|syntax|unit).*$' # jobs run on the proposal worker if re.match(proposal_re, job.name) or re.match(pypi_re, job.name): reusable_node(item, job, params) # Jobs needing python26 elif re.match(python26_re, job.name): # Pass because job specified label is always correct. pass # Jobs needing centos6 elif re.match(centos6_re, job.name): # Pass because job specified label is always correct. pass # Jobs needing fedora 20 elif re.match(f20_re, job.name): # Pass because job specified label is always correct. pass # Jobs needing fedora 21 elif re.match(f21_re, job.name): # Pass because job specified label is always correct. pass # Jobs needing tripleo slaves elif re.match(tripleo_re, job.name): # Pass because job specified label is always correct. pass # Puppet-OpenStack jobs elif re.match(puppetunit_re, job.name): pass # Jobs needing devstack slaves elif re.match(devstack_re, job.name): devstack_params(item, job, params) elif default == 'trusty': default_params_trusty(item, job, params) else: default_params_precise(item, job, params) def set_node_options_default_precise(item, job, params): set_node_options(item, job, params, 'precise') def set_node_options_default_trusty(item, job, params): set_node_options(item, job, params, 'trusty')

commit_message:
GlusterFS: passthrough devstack config

This patch provides the glusterfs devstack configuration through
DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG variable, rather than having devstack-gate
need to know about devstack glusterfs plugin.

Change-Id: I8150d54c1100814ca40e9f6471fd4e979d199967
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/36/151136/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
export DEVSTACK_LOCAL_CONFIG=$'enable_service glusterfs
ENABLED_BACKENDS=glusterfs:glusterfs
TEMPEST_STORAGE_PROTOCOL=gluster
GLUSTERFS_LOOPBACK_DISK_SIZE=8G
enable_plugin glusterfs https://github.com/stackforge/devstack-plugin-glusterfs.git'

commit_message:
Update chef-rake jobs to use chefdk and run on trusty

* added macro for installing chefdk (currently with version 0.4.0-1
  since chef does not provide a 'latest' link)
* switched from using ruby-191-prep in gate-{name}-chef-rake job to installing
  chefdk which should include the whole environment needed
* changed chef-rake-test builder to execute rake inside of the chefdk
  environment (test is omitted, since its the default job)
* removed the pin on precise for the gate-{name}-chef-rake job to use
  the current default trusty instead

Change-Id: I09e7465068d467395aafccd2de027000a1ec4143
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/96/152196/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Move extra routes processing to router classes

Move legacy and HA routers implementation of the extra
routes extension to their respective router classes.
Move the unit tests as well.

Partially-Implements: blueprint restructure-l3-agent
Change-Id: Iec642dde3e1f2ffdfae4cdfb9cbdc777cad52a39

commit_message:
Just directly access the callback attributes

Since we perform validation on the callbacks
in the constructor we don't need to continue being
cautious after that point so we can remove the
usage of getattr and just access the underlying
callback properties that must have already existed.

Change-Id: I0c86506488d139268cb30f6c346484b2e978697f

commit_message:
Revise Read-only volumes section

The commands introduced in Read-only volumes in emc-vnx-direct-driver.xml
are incorrect.

Replace them with 'cinder readonly-mode-update volume True'

Change-Id: I928b07cfc96545ab830b228103e91aae46ede0a7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/93/148493/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>OpenStack supports read-only volumes. Administrators can use following command to set a volume to read-only.</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput >cinder readonly-mode-update volume True</userinput></screen>
deleted_lines: <para>OpenStack supports read-only volumes. Either of the following commands can be used to set a volume to read-only.</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>cinder metadata volume set 'attached_mode'='ro'</userinput> <prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>cinder metadata volume set 'readonly'='True'</userinput></screen>

commit_message:
Initial spec for nova-network to neutron migration process

This change includes the basic spec template and the expected
end-user/deployer impact of the proposed process.  The proposed
process itself will be added in a followup change.

blueprint migration-from-nova-net

Change-Id: I800cf46b633f521da9a1e8aacddf2109f80ba952
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/23/147723/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ====================================== Migration from Nova-network to Neutron ====================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/migration-from-nova-net This blueprint describes the neutron part of the proposed way to migrate OpenStack deployments from nova-network to neutron. Problem Description =================== Nova-network is deprecated in favour of Neutron. We need to be able to migrate existing nova-network deployments prior to removing the deprecated nova-network functionality. This will require additional changes to both nova and neutron to support the migration. This document will describe the overall process and the features required in both neutron and nova. Proposed Change =============== Impact/Limitations ------------------ It is expected that individual deployments will vary greatly in details, specific technology choices, downtime and risk tolerances. Consequently, the process described here is not a "one size fits all" automated push-button tool but a series of steps that should be obvious to automate and customise to meet local needs. Without further customisation, the process described has the following impact: REST API Impact --------------- * Neutron REST API is read-only until after the migration is complete. * Nova REST API is available throughout the entire process, although there is a brief period where it is made read-only during a database migration. Performance Impact ------------------ * During the migration, nova network API calls will go through an additional internal conversion to neutron calls. This will have different (likely poorer) performance characteristics compared with either the pre-migration or post-migration APIs. VM Instance Impact ------------------ * In order to support a wide range of deployment options, the "dumb" process described here requires a rolling reboot of hypervisors. For specific before/after deployment options, a "smart" hit-less hypervisor migration may be possible. The process described here makes it easy to take advantage of a smart tool, but the implementation of such a tool is out of scope for this document. * The rate and timing of specific hypervisor reboots is under the control of the operator. The migration may pause for an extended period of time (for example, while testing or investigating issues) with some hypervisors on nova-network and some on neutron, and nova API remains fully functional. Supported Deployment Technologies --------------------------------- * This process supports any nova-network and neutron deployment options which are wire-compatible. For example, nova-network with VLANs can be migrated to neutron/ML2/OVS with VLANs (using the same VLAN ids). * Note that multi-host nova-network is not wire-compatible with neutron DVR and this migration path is not supported. Deployer Impact --------------- * In order to support the widest range of deployer needs, the process described here is easy to automate but is not already automated. Deployers should expect to perform multiple manual steps or write some simple scripts in order to perform this migration. Overall proposed migration process ---------------------------------- TODO Implementation ============== TODO Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: obondarev Other contributors: gus Work Items ---------- TODO Dependencies ============ TODO Testing ======= Grenade upgrade test -------------------- "Sideways" grenade test. Configure "old" cloud config using nova-net and "new" config using neutron. Grenade sets up "old", runs some tests, shuts it down, runs the "upgrade" steps, and fires up "new". The Grenade check passes if the tests pass against the "new" cluster. [#grenade_job]_ Other ----- We will need to confirm that the mid-point situation where some nodes are on nova-network and some are on neutron is able to forward east-west traffic and handle nova API calls as expected. This requires a multi-node scenario so may not be able to use our regular automated testing frameworks. Tempest Tests ------------- Existing tempest tests might be used during "sideways" grenade job (see above). However the main thing is to ensure objects (networks, instances, etc.) existing in the "old" cloud, migrate fine and continue to function properly in the "new" cloud. This will likely require adding new special tests for the job. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation should be added to the operators guide [#operators_guide]_ describing the whole neutron migration process in detail. References ========== .. [#grenade_job] "Sideways" grenade job proposal http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-October/047593.html .. [#operators_guide] Operators Guide https://github.com/openstack/operations-guide/blob/master/doc/openstack-ops/ch_ops_upgrades.xml

commit_message:
Move functional tests to keystone/tests/functional

This commit moves Keystone's functional tests to it's own directory and
adds a tox environment for running only functional tests. Keystone
functional tests can now be run with:

  $ tox -e functional

New functional tests for Keystone should be added to the
keystone/tests/functional/ directory.

Change-Id: I799090a2c2beb0ee68cf39fc06f9ddce2b7fa40f

commit_message:
Implementation of Brocade Vyatta Firewall driver

Change-Id: I87d895d5b576cb8e52ecd34ce2331f1f17504b0a
Implements: blueprint brocade-vyatta-fwaas-plugin
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-fwaas refs/changes/00/147600/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding:utf-8 -*- # Copyright 2014 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock import urllib from neutron.plugins.brocade.vyatta import client as vyatta_client from neutron.tests import base from neutron_fwaas.services.firewall.drivers.vyatta import vyatta_fwaas FAKE_FW_UUID = 'fake-fw-uuid' class VyattaFwaasTestCase(base.BaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(VyattaFwaasTestCase, self).setUp() self.fwaas_driver = vyatta_fwaas.VyattaFirewallDriver() # generic patches self.log = mock.Mock() self.patch(vyatta_fwaas, 'LOG', self.log) def test_create_firewall(self): fake_rules = [self._make_fake_fw_rule()] fake_firewall = self._make_fake_firewall(fake_rules) fake_apply_list = [self._make_fake_router_info()] fake_agent_mode = None with mock.patch.object( self.fwaas_driver, 'update_firewall') as fw_update: self.fwaas_driver.create_firewall( fake_agent_mode, fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) fw_update.assert_called_once_with( fake_agent_mode, fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) def test_update_firewall(self): fake_rules = [self._make_fake_fw_rule()] fake_firewall = self._make_fake_firewall(fake_rules) fake_apply_list = [self._make_fake_router_info()] fake_agent_mode = None with mock.patch.object( self.fwaas_driver, '_update_firewall') as fw_update: fake_firewall['admin_state_up'] = True self.fwaas_driver.create_firewall( fake_agent_mode, fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) fw_update.assert_called_once_with(fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) with mock.patch.object( self.fwaas_driver, 'apply_default_policy') as fw_apply_policy: fake_firewall['admin_state_up'] = False self.fwaas_driver.create_firewall( fake_agent_mode, fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) fw_apply_policy.assert_called_once_with( fake_agent_mode, fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) def test_delete_firewall(self): fake_rules = [self._make_fake_fw_rule()] fake_firewall = self._make_fake_firewall(fake_rules) fake_apply_list = [self._make_fake_router_info()] fake_agent_mode = None with mock.patch.object( self.fwaas_driver, 'apply_default_policy') as fw_apply_policy: self.fwaas_driver.delete_firewall( fake_agent_mode, fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) fw_apply_policy.assert_called_once_with( fake_agent_mode, fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) def test_apply_default_policy(self): fake_rules = [self._make_fake_fw_rule()] fake_firewall = self._make_fake_firewall(fake_rules) fake_apply_list = [self._make_fake_router_info()] fake_agent_mode = None # TODO(dbogun): is method logic ok? with mock.patch.object( self.fwaas_driver, '_delete_firewall') as fw_delete: self.fwaas_driver.apply_default_policy( fake_agent_mode, fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) calls = [mock.call(x, fake_firewall) for x in fake_apply_list] fw_delete.assert_has_calls(calls) def test__update_firewall(self): fake_rules = [self._make_fake_fw_rule()] fake_firewall = self._make_fake_firewall(fake_rules) fake_apply_list = [self._make_fake_router_info()] with mock.patch.object( self.fwaas_driver, '_delete_firewall' ) as fw_delete, mock.patch.object( self.fwaas_driver, '_setup_firewall') as fw_setup: self.fwaas_driver._update_firewall(fake_apply_list, fake_firewall) calls = [mock.call(x, fake_firewall) for x in fake_apply_list] fw_delete.assert_has_calls(calls) fw_setup.assert_has_calls(calls) def test__setup_firewall(self): fake_rule = self._make_fake_fw_rule() fake_firewall = self._make_fake_firewall([fake_rule]) fake_router_info = self._make_fake_router_info() fake_rule_cmd = 'fake-fw-rule0' fake_zone_configure_rules = ['fake-config-rule0'] mock_api = mock.Mock() mock_api_gen = mock.Mock(return_value=mock_api) mock_get_firewall_rule = mock.Mock(return_value=[fake_rule_cmd]) mock_get_zone_cmds = mock.Mock(return_value=fake_zone_configure_rules) with (mock.patch.object(self.fwaas_driver, '_get_vyatta_client', mock_api_gen), mock.patch.object(vyatta_fwaas.vyatta_utils, 'get_zone_cmds', mock_get_zone_cmds), mock.patch.object(self.fwaas_driver, '_set_firewall_rule', mock_get_firewall_rule)): self.fwaas_driver._setup_firewall(fake_router_info, fake_firewall) mock_api_gen.assert_called_once_with( fake_router_info.router) mock_get_firewall_rule.assert_called_once_with( fake_firewall['name'], 1, fake_rule) mock_get_zone_cmds.assert_called_once_with( mock_api, fake_router_info, fake_firewall['name']) cmds = [ vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/name/{0}'.format( # FIXME(dbgun): should be quoted fake_firewall['name'])), vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/name/{0}/description/{1}'.format( # FIXME(dbgun): should be quoted fake_firewall['name'], urllib.quote_plus(fake_firewall['description']))), vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/state-policy/established/action/accept'), vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/state-policy/related/action/accept'), fake_rule_cmd, ] + fake_zone_configure_rules mock_api.exec_cmd_batch.assert_called_once_with(cmds) def test__delete_firewall(self): fake_rule = self._make_fake_fw_rule() fake_firewall = self._make_fake_firewall([fake_rule]) fake_router_info = self._make_fake_router_info() with mock.patch.object( self.fwaas_driver, '_get_vyatta_client') as mock_client_factory: mock_api = mock_client_factory.return_value self.fwaas_driver._delete_firewall(fake_router_info, fake_firewall) cmds = [ vyatta_client.DeleteCmd("zone-policy"), vyatta_client.DeleteCmd("firewall/name/{0}".format( fake_firewall['name'])), vyatta_client.DeleteCmd("firewall/state-policy"), ] mock_api.exec_cmd_batch.assert_called_once_with(cmds) def test__set_firewall_rule(self): fake_rule = self._make_fake_fw_rule() fake_firewall_name = 'fake-fw-name' fake_rule.update({ 'description': 'rule description', 'source_port': '2080', 'destination_ip_address': '172.16.1.1' }) action_map = { 'allow': 'accept', } # FIXME(dbogun): deal with quoted/unquoted arguments. They must be all # quoted or all not quoted. cmds_actual = self.fwaas_driver._set_firewall_rule( fake_firewall_name, 1, fake_rule) cmds_expect = [ vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/name/{0}/rule/{1}/description/{2}'.format( urllib.quote_plus(fake_firewall_name), 1, urllib.quote_plus(fake_rule['description']))), vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/name/{0}/rule/{1}/protocol/{2}'.format( urllib.quote_plus(fake_firewall_name), 1, fake_rule['protocol'])), vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/name/{0}/rule/{1}/source/port/{2}'.format( urllib.quote_plus(fake_firewall_name), 1, urllib.quote_plus(fake_rule['source_port']))), vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/name/{0}/rule/{1}/destination/port/{2}'.format( urllib.quote_plus(fake_firewall_name), 1, urllib.quote_plus(fake_rule['destination_port']))), vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/name/{0}/rule/{1}/source/address/{2}'.format( urllib.quote_plus(fake_firewall_name), 1, urllib.quote_plus(fake_rule['source_ip_address']))), vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/name/{0}/rule/{1}/destination/address/{2}'.format( urllib.quote_plus(fake_firewall_name), 1, urllib.quote_plus(fake_rule['destination_ip_address']))), vyatta_client.SetCmd( 'firewall/name/{0}/rule/{1}/action/{2}'.format( urllib.quote_plus(fake_firewall_name), 1, action_map.get(fake_rule['action'], 'drop'))), ] self.assertEqual(cmds_expect, cmds_actual) def _make_fake_router_info(self): info = mock.Mock() info.router = { 'id': 'fake-router-id', 'tenant_id': 'tenant-uuid', } return info def _make_fake_fw_rule(self): return { 'enabled': True, 'action': 'allow', 'ip_version': 4, 'protocol': 'tcp', 'destination_port': '80', 'source_ip_address': '10.24.4.2'} def _make_fake_firewall(self, rules): return {'id': FAKE_FW_UUID, 'admin_state_up': True, 'name': 'test-firewall', 'tenant_id': 'tenant-uuid', 'description': 'Fake firewall', 'firewall_rule_list': rules}

commit_message:
Remove --skip-redirect form the tgtd service restart

skip-redirect was intruduced with the first commit related
to cinder support, nobody remembers why was this undocumented option
there those times.

commit_message:
Fix references to non-existent "pause" section

Two sections of the hypervisor support matrix refer readers to the
sections of the document dealing with the "pause" operation.
Although there is a section in the raw .ini file called
"[operation.pause]", this doesn't appear at all in the rendered
version of document since it's title is set to
"Stop instance CPUs".  This renders readers of the rendered
document unable to find sections being referenced.

This patch clears up the confusion by changing the references
to refer to "Stop instance CPUs" rather than "pause".

Change-Id: Ia97d8e400db3a11291a715f6a630ea8bc638993e
Closes-bug: #1418641

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/56/150856/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: How can I add a custom role? ---------------------------- Current Plugin Architecture does not provide a way to define role. Starting with Fuel 6.1 you can use Operating System role as a workaround. In **tasks.yaml** file use 'base-os' define deployment of the role. .. code-block:: yaml - role: ['base-os'] stage: post_deployment type: shell parameters: cmd: ./deploy.sh timeout: 42 In plugin documentation ask the user to assign Operating System role on required node and the name for the node with specific prefix, for example zabbix-01. In deployment script you can get the name from variable in astute.yaml file and decide if the script should deploy Zabbix related packages on the node. .. code-block:: yaml ... user_node_name: zabbix-01 ...

subject: Create SolidFire Template account on init
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-27 23:20:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/a3c1f6f7ab9017d8466ac0decb897282427f4295', 'message': 'Create SolidFire Template account on init

The standard flow in the SolidFire volume is to create
accounts dynamically as needed based on project id.
Unfortunately the clone_image method "forgot" about this
detail and calls the private clone_volume method without
a valid account resulting in an AccountNotFound
Exception.

The clone_image method is enabled using a specific account
provided via the configuration file.  Rather than worry
about dynamic account creation on clone_image call, this
patch just makes it part of the init phase.  We check to
see if template caching is enabled and if it is, just
go ahead and check/create the account on startup.

Change-Id: I41a8d400d3dfc0e185304f80efd419ebac9efdf6
Closes-Bug: #1414760

commit_message:
Create SolidFire Template account on init

The standard flow in the SolidFire volume is to create
accounts dynamically as needed based on project id.
Unfortunately the clone_image method "forgot" about this
detail and calls the private clone_volume method without
a valid account resulting in an AccountNotFound
Exception.

The clone_image method is enabled using a specific account
provided via the configuration file.  Rather than worry
about dynamic account creation on clone_image call, this
patch just makes it part of the init phase.  We check to
see if template caching is enabled and if it is, just
go ahead and check/create the account on startup.

Change-Id: I41a8d400d3dfc0e185304f80efd419ebac9efdf6
Closes-Bug: #1414760

commit_message:
Fix argument order in assertEqual: tests/test_nfs.py

The assertEqual in cinder/tests/test_nfs.py is using
incorrect argument order (observed, expected), which causes the
error message about mismatch to be reversed if the test case fails.
Change it to (expected, observed).

Change-Id: I7fec2e5df91369c3cae2adef3189e8bd86fe4480
Partial-Bug: #1259292

subject: Enable use of an /etc/cinder/lvm.conf file
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-01-20 23:36:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/36ce96e7fdbe94009d5b1886bae36c1ad873a2cb', 'message': 'Enable use of an /etc/cinder/lvm.conf file

During tempest and Rally runs we've noticed occasional
LVM command hangs (lvs, vgs and pvs), we've also gathered
enough data to show that we see very slow response times from
these commands almost all of the time.

It turns out that this seems to be an issue with us scanning
all devices during LVM operations, including devices that may
be Cinder Volumes that are attaching and detaching from the system.

Inspecting a run instrumented with strace shows a number of LVM
commands timing out due to the device being scanned being removed
during scan, and the LVM command in turn waiting until it times out
on the scan that's in process.

This patch just adds the ability to setup a lvm.conf file in
/etc/cinder.  The Cinder LVM code will now specifically set
the LVM_SYSTEM_DIR environment variable to that directory for
each of the LVM scan commands in brick/local_dev/lvm.py.
If the system doesn't have the file, we use the empty string
which tells LVM to use it's defaults.  This only affects LVM
commands in Cinder, the idea is to ensure we don't impact any
other LVM operations on the node outside of Cinder and that we
behave as we always have in the case of no lvm.conf file being
setup in /etc/cinder.  The presence of the file is auto-detected
on brick/localdev/lvm init.

We'll update the OpenStack Devstack deployment scripts to put this
together and fix things up there first. Until that's done and until
we auto-generate the conf (or document it well), this will be a
*partial* bugfix.

I considered adding a default lvm.conf file to cinder/etc/<sample>
that would be copied in on install, but decided against this to
avoid any possible issues with compatability issues between
platforms or versions.

To use, just copy the /etc/lvm/lvm.conf file to /etc/cinder and
modify the filter as appropriate, for example:
  To use loopback device only:
    filter = [ "a/loop/", "r/.*/" ]
  If you have a physical drive like /dev/sdb1
    filter = [ "a/dev/sdb1/", "r/.*/" ]

Finally, this patch also goes through and cleans up our cmd
variables in brick/localdev/lvm.  We had a mix of using a
cmd array, and strings; this causes inconsistencies and makes
it difficult to extend or modify commands.  Switch everything to
using an array and use extend to provide the correct prefix.

Need to update docs to include a recommendation to create an
/etc/cinder/lvm.conf file and set device filters appropriately.
Doc-Impact
Partial-Bug: #1373513

Change-Id: Ia2289197a6d7fcfc910ee3de48e0a2173881a1e6

commit_message:
Enable use of an /etc/cinder/lvm.conf file

During tempest and Rally runs we've noticed occasional
LVM command hangs (lvs, vgs and pvs), we've also gathered
enough data to show that we see very slow response times from
these commands almost all of the time.

It turns out that this seems to be an issue with us scanning
all devices during LVM operations, including devices that may
be Cinder Volumes that are attaching and detaching from the system.

Inspecting a run instrumented with strace shows a number of LVM
commands timing out due to the device being scanned being removed
during scan, and the LVM command in turn waiting until it times out
on the scan that's in process.

This patch just adds the ability to setup a lvm.conf file in
/etc/cinder.  The Cinder LVM code will now specifically set
the LVM_SYSTEM_DIR environment variable to that directory for
each of the LVM scan commands in brick/local_dev/lvm.py.
If the system doesn't have the file, we use the empty string
which tells LVM to use it's defaults.  This only affects LVM
commands in Cinder, the idea is to ensure we don't impact any
other LVM operations on the node outside of Cinder and that we
behave as we always have in the case of no lvm.conf file being
setup in /etc/cinder.  The presence of the file is auto-detected
on brick/localdev/lvm init.

We'll update the OpenStack Devstack deployment scripts to put this
together and fix things up there first. Until that's done and until
we auto-generate the conf (or document it well), this will be a
*partial* bugfix.

I considered adding a default lvm.conf file to cinder/etc/<sample>
that would be copied in on install, but decided against this to
avoid any possible issues with compatability issues between
platforms or versions.

To use, just copy the /etc/lvm/lvm.conf file to /etc/cinder and
modify the filter as appropriate, for example:
  To use loopback device only:
    filter = [ "a/loop/", "r/.*/" ]
  If you have a physical drive like /dev/sdb1
    filter = [ "a/dev/sdb1/", "r/.*/" ]

Finally, this patch also goes through and cleans up our cmd
variables in brick/localdev/lvm.  We had a mix of using a
cmd array, and strings; this causes inconsistencies and makes
it difficult to extend or modify commands.  Switch everything to
using an array and use extend to provide the correct prefix.

Need to update docs to include a recommendation to create an
/etc/cinder/lvm.conf file and set device filters appropriately.
Doc-Impact
Partial-Bug: #1373513

Change-Id: Ia2289197a6d7fcfc910ee3de48e0a2173881a1e6

commit_message:
Provide more details about testing strategies

With the decomp running at full steam, some questions have been
raised on Gerrit, IRC or the mailing list. This patch adds more
details on how to go about unit testing and some current limitations
of 3rd party systems.

Partial-implements: blueprint core-vendor-decomposition

Change-Id: I3920bb394d57de126fd0de8a238f7b710baa1075
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/07/152707/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * No unit tests for the vendor integration of plugins and drivers are deemed necessary. The expectation is that contributors would run unit test in their own external library (e.g. in stackforge where Jenkins setup is for free). For unit tests that validate the vendor library, it is the responsibility of the vendor to choose what CI system they see fit to run them. There is no need or requirement to use OpenStack CI resources if they do not want to. Having said that, it may be useful to provide coverage for the shim layer in the form of basic validation as done in `ODL <https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/tests/unit/ml2/test_mechanism_odl.py>`_ and `LBaaS A10 driver <https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lbaas/blob/master/neutron_lbaas/tests/unit/services/loadbalancer/drivers/a10networks/test_driver_v1.py>`_. It is worth noting that if the vendor library is hosted on StackForge, due to current openstack-infra limitations, it is not possible to have 3rd CI systems participating in the gate pipeline. This means that the only validation provided during the merge process is through unit tests. Post-merge hooks can still be exploited to provide 3rd CI feedback, and alert the contributor/reviewer of potential issues.
deleted_lines: * There will be no unit tests for plugins and drivers in the tree; The expectation is that contributors would run unit test in their own external library (e.g. in stackforge where Jenkins setup is for free). For unit tests that validate the vendor library, it is the responsibility of the vendor to choose what CI system they see fit to run them. There is no need or requirement to use OpenStack CI resources if they do not want to.

commit_message:
Restore and fix vmware unit tests

This patch actually restores vmware unit tests, by adding back
the __init__.py file which was renamed during the advanced
service spinoff and not reinstated when fixing vmware code to
comply with the spinoff.

Furthermore, this patch also fixes a minor issue with context
usage in vmware unit tests which is triggering failures because
of the new database constraint introduced with the commit
79c97120de9cff4d0992b5d41ff4bbf05e890f89

Finally, flake8 tests on vmware directories are also restored
with this patch.

Change-Id: Ib63463fca28bbb4a1eb60b8f5f4b63b3d3367c9e
Closes-Bug: #1416593
Closes-Bug: #1416596

commit_message:
Provide option to disable storing of extra attributes in SQL

Change-Id: I5269aad9afb5c997232572dc623387e433f2e5cd
Blueprint: extra-optional
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/39/151939/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================= Make storing of extra SQL attributes optional ============================================= `bp extra-optional <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/extra-optional>`_ Allow a cloud provider to disable the storing of "extra" SQL attributes. Problem Description =================== Our SQL drivers have for a long time supported clients piggybacking on our formal entity attributes by just including extra attributes in the API call (e.g. POST) - which we then store in the 'extras' column. While this is used by a number of customers, it's a practice we don't want to encourage. Moreover, allowing this could mean that cloud providers are unintentionally storing PII information if the client includes such attributes in their API calls. Proposed Change =============== We will provide a configuration option to define whether our SQL drivers will store extra attributes. For backward compatibility this will be set, by default, to allow such storage. Disabling this option will cause any extra parameters to be silently ignored in both read and write of SQL entities. If this option is disabled on a system that already has extra attributes stored this data will not be deleted - that is left as an out-of-band operation for the cloud provider. As an aside, although we do support extra attributes for LDAP drivers, the storage of these is already optional by virtue of the fact that a mapping must be defined in the LDAP section of the configuration file. Alternatives ------------ None Security Impact --------------- This should close a potential security loophole. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Henry Nash (henry-nash) Work Items ---------- * Create configuration option * Honor that option in the core SQL code when converts the extra attributes Dependencies ============ None Documentation Impact ==================== Update to the configuration.rst References ========== None

commit_message:
Allow to find resource with digit name

Initially, when we are trying to create a
volume by the name of numbers [0011] then
volume is created with that name but when
we are trying to delete/show this volume
then " Not Found (HTTP 404) " error occurs.
because method 'find_resource' taking digit
name as id.

Now by adding 'is_alphanum_id_allowed'
attribute to manager, alphanum id will allow
for the resource. With this patch we will be
able to delete the volume what we created.

Change-Id: Ib4dfaa9f15961fadc1a322bcf57f636e0f28fecf
Closes-bug: #1398814
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/37/141337/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if isinstance(name_or_id, str): return manager.get(str(name_or_id))
deleted_lines: if isinstance(name_or_id, int) or name_or_id.isdigit(): return manager.get(int(name_or_id))

commit_message:
Do not create floating-ip-bulk when not existing pool is set

Initially, when create floating-ip-bulk with not
existing 'pool' option, no exception is raise
and floating-ip-bulk can be created
successfully.

Now, this patch makes it return 400 to client.

Change-Id: Ia28e611acf1288243594db3c9cf9ac89996ef5be
Closes-Bug: #1377072

commit_message:
Pass root_helper to ip_lib by keyword argument to prep for removal

To assist in being able to stop passing the root_helper option to
various classes/functions and instead handle root_helper just in
execute(), pass root_helper in advanced services via keyword
argument, so that the root_helper removal patch will be able to
accept, but ignore it and still have tests pass.

Change-Id: Icb9d638cf4215ec3be71cfa4fac9ca7781e6221c

commit_message:
Set default severity of Alarm Definitions to LOW

API spec doc says default severity is LOW so initialize it

API spec doc also says that severiy is upper case so change to match
that

Change-Id: I423847a4e2384b795595edea020f0d500cb3644b

commit_message:
Basic-Auth middleware

A simple middleware that allows setting and testing the REMOTE_USER
env var based on a user lookup.
Users log in with user_id and password.

Blueprint: basic-auth

Change-Id: If3acef59a7f61593dff016656d645c26d3d4b31a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/37/92137/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.common import dependencyfrom keystone import exceptionfrom keystone.middleware import basic_auth @dependency.provider('identity_api') class MockIdentity(object): _users = dict() def valid_user(self, user_id, password): self._users[user_id] = password def authenticate(self, context, user_id, password, domain_scope=None): test_user_password = self._users.get(user_id) if test_user_password is None: raise(exception.UserNotFound(user_id)) if test_user_password != password: raise(exception.UserNotFound(user_id)) class BasicAuthMiddlewareTest(tests.TestCase): def test_basic_auth_success(self): id = MockIdentity() id.valid_user('Aladdin', 'open sesame') req = make_request(body='{}', content_type='application/json', method='POST') req.headers['Authorization'] = 'Basic QWxhZGRpbjpvcGVuIHNlc2FtZQ==' basic_auth.BasicAuthMiddleware(None).process_request(req) self.assertEqual('Aladdin', req.environ['REMOTE_USER']) def test_basic_auth_bad_password(self): id = MockIdentity() id.valid_user('Aladdin', 'bad password') req = make_request(body='{}', content_type='application/json', method='POST') req.headers['Authorization'] = 'Basic QWxhZGRpbjpvcGVuIHNlc2FtZQ==' middleware = basic_auth.BasicAuthMiddleware(None) self.assertRaises(exception.UserNotFound, middleware.process_request, req) def test_basic_auth_missing_user(self): id = MockIdentity() id.valid_user('Jaffar', 'bad password') req = make_request(body='{}', content_type='application/json', method='POST') req.headers['Authorization'] = 'Basic QWxhZGRpbjpvcGVuIHNlc2FtZQ==' middleware = basic_auth.BasicAuthMiddleware(None) self.assertRaises(exception.UserNotFound, middleware.process_request, req)

subject: Update network resource when shelve offload instance
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-31 07:36:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/4886dd741a0dda9eb7d944fecb4c6918ea304ae9', 'message': "Update network resource when shelve offload instance

Commit: 4f8185549dfe11eb1ce405711593baa1528045ea fixes the problem
of update binding when unshelve instance for neutron. But that fixing
didn't cover the case for nova-network. For nova-network with multi
host, the floating ip should be removed when shelve offload instance.

Commit: 4f8185549dfe11eb1ce405711593baa1528045ea fixes the problem
by invoke migrate_instance_finish function. But that function should
be used by only for migration case. This patch use the new network api
'setup_instance_network_on_host' to update network for instance.

Also for nova-network, floating-ip should cleanup when unshelve offload
instance. This patch invoke cleanup_instance_network_on_host when unshelve
offload instance.

Change-Id: I75df695ec7b14ebaa25f384ba9a0697a179af03a

commit_message:
Update network resource when shelve offload instance

Commit: 4f8185549dfe11eb1ce405711593baa1528045ea fixes the problem
by invoke migrate_instance_finish function. But that function should
be used by only for migration case. This patch use the new network api
'setup_instance_network_on_host' to update network for instance.

Also for nova-network, floating-ip should cleanup when unshelve offload
instance. This patch invoke cleanup_instance_network_on_host when unshelve
offload instance.

Change-Id: I75df695ec7b14ebaa25f384ba9a0697a179af03a
Closes-Bug: #1350704

commit_message:
Add entry points for option discovery

Create entry points for oslo.policy, and make the necessary
changes to grouping the options into a new 'oslo_policy' group.

Change-Id: I32fd78c8a90fd2d49824db145362069b81fcaec5
Closes-Bug: #1415631

commit_message:
run-layout: Portability improvements

* find -printf option seems like a GNU extension.
  Use xargs + basename instead.

* sh is more available than bash.  Fortunately we don't actually
  rely on bash specific features here.

Change-Id: If1d9ce5cd361b47d6b2c4bb3f714dbc1cb07966b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/65/150265/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/sh -efind jenkins-job-builder/.test/new/out/ | xargs -n1 basename > job-list.txt

commit_message:
Enable voting for osc-functional

We haven't had a failed job in a while, aside from legit failures.
So let's get rid of the non-voting logic.

Change-Id: I0ccc88f0233d25196ff1f40eb11d7a8624f884db

Enable jobs to publish cross-project specs

We now have a real cross project spec (logging guidelines), so we should
start publishing the approved specs.

commit_message:
Software Metadata Definitions

The spec will provide a base library of metadata definitions for
various common software products, components, and libraries that
may exist on particular image (or volume or instance). These
metadata definitions will make it easier for end users and
admins to easily describe the software and its properties.
This information will enable an improved and faster user
experience for applying software metadata, searching based
on software metadata, and viewing the software information
about an image.

Various improvements in horizon are underway to take
advantage of this metadata. For example, a user launching
an instance will be able to expand the image row to see
additional information about the image.  This will include
providing the metadata definition for properties on the image.
This same information will also be visible from the image and
instance details page.

Implements: blueprint software-metadefs
Change-Id: I70c13d1c903ef4b447eaaeb4c3af40a4cbfb3c71
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance-specs refs/changes/04/148004/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Software Metadata Definitions ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/glance/+spec/software-metadefs The spec will provide a base library of metadata definitions for various common software products, components, and libraries that may exist on particular image (or volume or instance). These metadata definitions will make it easier for end users and admins to easily describe the software and its properties. This information will enable an improved and faster user experience for applying software metadata, searching based on software metadata, and viewing the software information about an image. Various improvements in horizon are underway to take advantage of this metadata. For example, a user launching an instance will be able to expand the image row to see addition information about the image. This will include providing the metadata definition for properties on the image. This same information will also be visible from the image and instance details page. The following screenshot mockup provides an example from the instance details: https://wiki.openstack.org/w/images/3/37/Instance-details-mock-january-2015.png Problem description =================== In Juno, the metadata definitions catalog was introduced with a primary intent to improve collaboration on the metadata that can be applied to different resources such as images, flavors, host aggregates, and volumes. The primary development focus in Juno was on what is currently system metadata in OpenStack (properties that affect scheduling and driver behavior). The metadata fields on these same resources can also be used to provide additional, rich information that describes the resource for user understanding and search. This information can be leveraged to improve instance launching, application catalogs, and a variety of other user interaction points. Current methodologies present and proposed in OpenStack require repetitive descriptions, categorization, imagery, and attributes to be applied on each instance of a resource. For example, if multiple images contain Apache then each image will require the user to type in information about Apache, will require them to provide some sort of categorization tag, and will not have any common "template" like fields for the software which can be used for faceted search. This leads to redundancy, spelling mistakes, inconsistency as well as a general lack of ability to present a rich UI experience. In addition, there is no common set of base definitions for software that can be shared across deployments. Proposed change =============== This will provide a base library of metadata definitions for various common software products, components, and libraries that may exist on particular image (or volume or instance). These metadata definitions will make it easier for end users and admins to easily describe the software and its properties. This information will enable an improved and faster user experience for applying software metadata, searching based on software metadata, and viewing the software information about an image. Alternatives ------------ Every single image, artifact, or other type of resource is added to the system, the admin could be responsible for putting a good description that is consistent with other descriptions, could try to remember all the right tags to add, could upload a new to directly associate with it. This leads to redundancy, spelling mistakes, inconsistency as well as a general lack of ability to present a rich UI experience. It also doesn't enable predictable search facets for rich search experience. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- No impacts glance client. Work is being done in horizon to take better advantage of these definitions. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers will be provided with a base set of metadata definitions for software similar to what they are provided for system metadata definitions. They can choose to not use the base definitions provided. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: travis-tripp Other contributors: lakshmi-sampath murali-sundar Reviewers --------- Core reviewer(s): <launchpad-id or None> <launchpad-id or None> Other reviewer(s): wayne-okuma Work Items ---------- Provide definition files for different categories of software. - Databases - Web servers - Runtime environments - More Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Existing code ensures that metadata definitions are loaded properly. Documentation Impact ==================== Possibly update docs to talk about the base software definitions provided. References ========== http://docs.openstack.org/developer/glance/metadefs-concepts.html

commit_message:
use precise marker function for log message translation

According to guidelines http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html
we can/should use _LI, _LW, _LE, _LC for different log level messages
to lower translation burden.

This patch adds hacking checks to follow i18n's guide, and fixes some
string interpolation issues for log messages.

Change-Id: I9a9f87c78670150df75919be9e0e5669b296cb30
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/41/153441/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: For log message translation issue, see guidelines: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html - [C300] Check for oslo library imports use the non-namespaced packages - [C301] Use _LC() for critical log level message translation - [C302] Use _LE() for exception log level message translation - [C303] Use _LE() for error log level message translation - [C304] Use _LW() for warn log level message translation - [C305] Use _LI() for info log level message translation

subject: Create a reusable angular-based wizard
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-11-26 17:24:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/6fa076bb757544b9f6bb80c1941cb3f1e46f1555', 'message': 'Implements: blueprint BASIC WIZARD FRAMEWORK

Change-Id: I6d7530b6723764d3ca117e16eeae78c0ab35e48e
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-12-02 00:34:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/536052f8a6e86ee25d09234e66b6efdd689e7bc6', 'message': 'Change topic and description format for this patch.

Summary:
Create a reusable angular based wizard.

Motivation:
The initial driving motivation is to redesign the launch instance wizard based on a modern, responsive design that is based on client side rendering using angular.

The wizard will be as lightweight as possible, but still allow for customizable text, localization, customizable per-worfklow number of steps.

Change Description:
This is a first step to setup how an angular based wizard framework basic code structure would look like. This change includes:

- A directive for wizard as a whole container, can be used as extended html element or attribute.
- A directive for wizard-step for each step in a wizard workflow, can be used as extendeed html element or attribute.
- A augular html template for wizard directive.
- A angular html template for wizard step directive.
- A style file in scss format (_wizard.scss) containing CSS rules for wizard container.
- Some unit tests using Jasmine.
- Modified _scripts.html to integrate new JavaScript files.
- Modified horizon.scss to integrate new scss file.
- Add app wide constants in `hz` module.

Change-Id: I6d7530b6723764d3ca117e16eeae78c0ab35e48e
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2014-12-03 00:57:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/f754b6b936b750d52da0ea75289ecb49cb8100f5', 'message': 'Enable wizard populating steps from workflow

Reimplementing wizard directive and remove wizard-step directive which
no longer needed with the new wizard directive implementation.

This patch is a part of implementing blueprint: Create a reusable
angular based wizard.

blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/horizon/+spec/initial-reusable-angular-wizard

Change-Id: I6d7530b6723764d3ca117e16eeae78c0ab35e48e
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-12-03 05:59:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/5b7957b4e0735cd65c13473ef4211452913aa8fb', 'message': 'Create a reusable angular based wizard

Motivation:
The initial driving motivation is to redesign the launch instance wizard
based on a modern, responsive design that is based on client side
rendering using angular.

Description:
The wizard will be as lightweight as possible, but still allow for
customizable text, localization, customizable per-worfklow number of
steps.

Design:
- Create a wizard directive which handles all wizard UI logic, including
  navigating between wizard steps, disabling and enabling navigation
  buttons and tabs, marking step status, listening demanding events.
- Create an external template for the wizard directive.
- The wizard directive should have a `workflow` attribute specifying a
  a workflow name for a workflow definition.  The definition should be
  defined in angular factory service and there be able to inject into
  wizard directive to populate the whole wizard.  This is how the UI
  logic and business logic is linked.
- CSS style should be implemented in a single file and all the rules
  about it should be namespaced under .wizard.
- Use Jasmine for unit test.

Blueprint:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/horizon/+spec/initial-reusable-angular-wizard

Change-Id: I6d7530b6723764d3ca117e16eeae78c0ab35e48e
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2014-12-03 07:48:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/dc0d77a0cdb06d5d27cce05cb550121da3ae6db0', 'message': 'Create a reusable angular based wizard

  navigating between wizard steps, disabling and enabling navigation
  buttons and tabs, marking step status, listening demanding events.
* Create an external template for the wizard directive.
* The wizard directive should have a `workflow` attribute specifying a
  a workflow name for a workflow definition.  The definition should be
  defined in angular factory service and there be able to inject into
  wizard directive to populate the whole wizard.  This is how the UI
  logic and business logic is linked.
* CSS style should be implemented in a single file and all the rules
  about it should be namespaced under .wizard.
* Use Jasmine for unit test.

Implements: blueprint initial-reusable-angular-wizard
Change-Id: I6d7530b6723764d3ca117e16eeae78c0ab35e48e

commit_message:
Create a reusable angular-based wizard

Motivation:
The initial driving motivation is to redesign the launch instance wizard
based on a modern, responsive design that is based on client side
rendering using angular.

Description:
The wizard will be as lightweight as possible, but still allow for
customizable text, localization, customizable per-worfklow number of
steps.

Design:
* Angular-based.
* Using Angular Bootstrap UI modal widget.

Co-Authored-By: Shaoquan Chen <sean.chen2@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Szymon Wroblewski <szymon.wroblewski@intel.com>
Implements: blueprint initial-reusable-angular-wizard
Change-Id: I6d7530b6723764d3ca117e16eeae78c0ab35e48e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/17/137417/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Change-Id: I5417f74d324b1915155e321c3a87138069aa35fa
